text.title: Format a Write Protected USB on PC or Mac
text.head: Format a Write Protected USB on PC or Mac
text.p: This wikiHow teaches you how to remove write protection from a USB drive so you can format it in Windows or macOS.
text.head: Steps
Windows

list.item: Check if the drive has a write-protect switch. If it does, just switch it off, then you can proceed with formatting. If not, continue to the next step.
Plug the drive’s USB cable into a USB port on the PC.
Press . This opens the Run dialog.

Type and click . This opens a terminal window displaying a command prompt.
If you see a “User Account Control” window, click Yes to proceed.
Type and press . This lists the drives connected to the computer, including those inside.
Find the number of your USB drive. The drives are labeled Disk 0, Disk 1, Disk 2, etc. You can tell from the size which one is the USB drive.
Type and press . Replace [number] with the number next to your USB drive (e.g. Select Disk 1). You’ll see a message that says “Disk [number] is now the selected disk.
Type and press . This removes the write protection attribute on the drive. Once the process is complete, you’ll see a message telling you that the attributes have been successfully cleared.
Type and press . This erases the data on the drive.
Type and press . This creates a new partition so you can format the drive. Once you return to the “DISKPART>” prompt, you can close the window by clicking the X at its top-right corner.
Press to open the File Explorer. This displays the files and drives on your PC.
Scroll down the left column and right-click the USB drive. It should be near the bottom of the column. A context menu will appear.
Click . A dialog box with several formatting options will appear.

Select an option from the “File system” drop-down menu.
FAT: Only compatible with drives 32GB or smaller. Windows and Mac compatible.
NTFS: Windows compatible only.
exFAT: Compatible with Windows and Mac.
Type a name for the drive. This goes into the “Volume Label” box.
Click . It’s at the bottom of the window. A warning pop-up will appear, reminding you that formatting erases the disk data.
Click . This formats the drive, which may take several minutes. A pop-up will appear when it’s finished.
Click . The drive is now ready to use.

text.head: macOS

list.item: Check if the drive has a write-protect switch. If it does, just switch it off, then you can proceed with formatting. If not, continue to the next step.
Plug the drive’s USB cable into a USB port on the Mac.
Open Finder . You’ll find it on the left side of your Mac’s Dock.
Click the menu. It’s at the top of the screen.
Click .
Double-click . It’s the icon containing a hard drive and a stethoscope.
Click your USB drive. It’s in the left column.
Click .
Enter a new name for the drive. This is how the drive will be labeled.

Select a file format. Click the “Format” drop-down menu and select one of the following file formats:
Mac OS Extended (Journaled): Compatible with Mac only.
MS-DOS (FAT): Only for drives 32 GBs or smaller. Windows and Mac compatible.
ExFAT: No size limits. Windows and Mac compatible.
Click . This formats the drive.
Click . You can now use the drive.
